Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister breached s. 47.1 of the Canadian Wheat Board Act by failing to consult and obtain producer consent before introducing Bill C-18
Evidence_Assessment: Minister introduced Bill C-18 without consultation or vote; court assessed statutory language and legislative intent
Decision_Outcome: Declarations granted that the Minister breached s. 47.1
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants (CWB and producers) to demonstrate statutory breach
Legal_Rule: Section 47.1 requires consultation with CWB and producer consent via vote before introducing legislation that alters the marketing mandate or structure
Procedural_Issue: Failure to follow mandatory consultation and consent procedures under s. 47.1
Grounds_for_Claim: Minister's unilateral action contrary to statutory requirements
Review_Standard: Interpretation of statutory provisions in accordance with principles of statutory interpretation
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Procedural fairness required under statutory scheme; Minister failed to uphold it
Key_Evidence_Considered: Text of s. 47.1, legislative history, nature of changes in Bill C-18
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, rule of law, statutory interpretation
Applicant_Challenge: Challenge to legality of Ministerâ€™s failure to comply with s. 47.1 prior to introducing Bill C-18
Court_Result: Court declared that the Minister breached s. 47.1
Defendant_Response: Minister argued s. 47.1 applies only to grain inclusion/exclusion, not repeal of the Act
Remedy_Requested: Declarations of breach and failure to meet legitimate expectations
Applicable_Process: Legislative amendment process requiring consultation and producer vote
Outcome_of_Review: Minister found to have breached statutory duty
Governing_Rule: s. 47.1 of the Canadian Wheat Board Act
